dc:description: LRRC10 was evaluated for autosomal recessive dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). LRRC10 was originally evaluated for DCM by the ClinGen DCM GCEP on March 20, 2020. Evidence of the association of this gene with DCM was re-evaluated using SOP v10 on August 9, 2024. As a result, the classification did not change. A summary of the information contributing to the classification of this gene at the time of re-evaluation is summarized herein. There is a lack of robust human genetic evidence demonstrating this gene-disease relationship in the literature at the time of curation. Two publications were reviewed in regards to human genetic evidence, but neither was felt to meet the threshold for scoring. The variant reported by Woon et al. 2018 (PMID: 29431102) has subsequently been found at a frequency higher than would be expected for a monogenic, pathogenic effect in population reference data sets. The second publication that presented genetic evidence was excluded due to DCM GCEP concerns of suspect data (Qu et al, 2015, PMID 26017719). This gene-disease assertion is supported by animal models, expression studies, and protein interaction studies. LRRC10 expression in the heart has been demonstrated in both mice and zebrafish (Kim et al, 2007, PMID: 17626279; Kim et al, 2007, PMID: 17601532; Brody et al, 2013, PMID: 23751912). Protein interaction studies demonstrate interaction with ACTC1, GATA4, and NKX2-5 (Brody et al 2012, PMID: 23236519; Brody et al, 2013, PMID: 23751912; Brody et al, 2016, PMID: 26608339). Knockout LRRC10 animal models have been shown to develop dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure (Brody et al 2012, PMID: 23236519; Kim et al, 2007, PMID: 17601532; Brody et al, 2013, PMID: 23751912). However, the DCM GCEP elected to reduce the points awarded for animal models given the mode of inheritance has not been confirmed in any human genetic evidence data and a knockout model is a severe genetic manipulation. Overall, no convincing evidence for a causal role for LRRC10 and autosomal recessive DCM has been reported. Although this gene-disease assertion is supported by animal models, expression studies, and protein interaction studies, no reports have directly implicated the gene in humans. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on August 9, 2024 (SOP Version 10).
curationReasonDescription: All case-level evidence and case-control evidence was reviewed by the expert panel and found to have significant limitations. As a result, neither paper received points.

evidence.dc:description: Author's did not provide any statistical analysis. Calculating Fisher's Exact T-test the p-value is not significant (p=0.27).

The paper itself did not provide any statistical analysis. Calculating the OR ourselves indicates an odds ratio of 1.25. We did not go on to calculate the confidence interval and p-value were not calculated. One variant identified in the case and control population, p.A151A, may be a polymorphism. It was seen in two cases and nine controls. It is seen in 3% of the East Asian population in ExAC. Additionally, it is not mentioned how the genotype analysis was performed in the controls.

caseCohort.detectionMethod: Individuals with a variant in LRRC10 then had NGS for an 80 gene arrhythmia panel

controlCohort.detectionMethod: There is no information on genotyping method for controls

evidence.dc:description: There is only one affected individual. Additionally, the healthy 8 year old brother also was homozygous for this variant.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1

member.rdfs:label: II.2
member.detectionMethod: Exome trio including the proband and her unaffected parents. These results were then filtered for de novo, compound heterozygous, and homozygous variants. Two de novo variants were identified in TTC28 and RIMKLA. Both of these genes have low expression levels in cardiac tissue.  Compound heterozygous variants were identified in SSC5D which is a gene associated with the immune system. The only homozygous variant is the variant in LRRC10.

evidence.dc:description: high gnomAD frequency (0.5%) and high incidence of homozygous cases in gnomAD (n=30)
affected calcium currents (decreased and more polarized potentials)
Yeast two hybrid screen indicates alpha-actinin is a binding partner for LRRC10.
evidence.rdfs:label: LRRC10 and actin Yeast hybrid screen

evidence.dc:description: Authors used whole-mount in situ hybridization of zebrafish embryos using an antisense zlrrc10 probe. LRRC10 was not detected in any tissues beyond cardiomyocytes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Tissue expression in zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: LRRC10 colocalized with the Z-line associated protein cardiac α-actinin
evidence.rdfs:label: Colocalization with actin

evidence.dc:description: In vitro pull down assays showed when the variant (p.His150Ala) was present, this affected binding with ACTC1. Control did interact with ACTC1 as expected.
evidence.rdfs:label: Binding with Actin

evidence.dc:description: qChIP was performed on wildtype (WT) and NKX2.5 knockout mouse hearts using NKX2.5, GATA4 and LRRC10 primers. There was a significantly lower mRNA level for LRRC10 in the knockout mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoprecipitation LRRC10 with NKX2.5

evidence.dc:description: Pulled down protein with immunoblotting showed co-localization with alpha actin.
evidence.rdfs:label: Pull Down experiment ACTC1

evidence.dc:description:
In situ hybridization using digocigenin-labeled LRRC10 along with a Northern blot from mouse heart shows LRRC10 is expressed in cardiac tissue. It is not expressed in other tissues in the mouse. Additionally, the Northern blot shows expression increases during embryonic development.

Immunohistochemical staining shows LRRC10 is detected in both the nucleus and cytoplasm in cardiomyocytes. Speciifically the authors demonstrated co localization near Z-line in cardiomyocytes.
evidence.rdfs:label: LRRC10 expression in mouse embryos

evidence.dc:description: Reduced expression of LRRC10 in NKX2-5 knockout mice using whole mount in situ hybridization
evidence.rdfs:label: Whole Mount in situ hybridization

evidence.dc:description: , Western blotting was performed on mouse heart extracts at various ages which showed expression throughout the mouse life cycle
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in mouse hearts (embryonic to adult)

evidence.dc:description: Not a proven mechanism of disease
Calcium currents were reduced in cells with variant
evidence.rdfs:label: Calcium Current in LRRC10 null Mice

evidence.dc:description: Baseline the null mice did not show a difference in contractility compared to controls--only under stress did the authors report a difference in contractility between cases and controls
cardiomyocytes from LRRC10 -/- mice exhibited reduced contractility under stress. Baseline the null mice did not show a difference in contractility compared to controls
evidence.rdfs:label: Contractility

evidence.dc:description: Not specific to the DCM phenotype. Score reduced further due to no confirmed inheritance in human studies and the severity of the genetic alteration required to develop the phenotype.
Decreased myocardial scar and increased cytokinesis
evidence.rdfs:label: LRRC10 Null Mouse Rescue

evidence.dc:description: Reduced all knockout models for LRRC10 due to the severity of this type of model and it only being consistent with AR MOI despite the MOI being unclear for this gene.

Mice have exacerbated cardiomyopathy in response to pressure overload. LRRC10 null mice developed significant left ventricular dilation and fractional shortening compared to controls. Stess exacerbated this phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse Model under stress

evidence.dc:description: Reduced all knockout models for LRRC10 due to the severity of this type of model and it only being consistent with AR MOI despite the MOI being unclear for this gene.

Mice exhibit prenatal systolic dysfunction and dilated cardiomyopathy in postnatal life.
Beginning at 1 month of age the mice developed left ventricular enlargement and fractional shortening which are both signs of DCM in humans.
evidence.rdfs:label: LRRC10 Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: Reduced all knockout models for LRRC10 due to the severity of this type of model and it only being consistent with AR MOI despite the MOI being unclear for this gene. Of note, the zebrafish also show heart looping defects suggesting maybe a congenital heart disease model instead of DCM .

Beginning three days post-fertilization, zebrafish started to develop signs of dilated cardiomyopathy including edema, a reduced ejection fraction, decreased stroke volume, and reduced cardiac output.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish animal model

evidence.dc:description: Phenotypically not specific to dilated cardiomyopathy. Score reduced further due to no confirmed inheritance in human studies and the severity of the genetic alteration required to develop the phenotype.
Lrrc10–/– mice showed increased scar size and incomplete myocardial regeneration in comparison to control hearts
evidence.rdfs:label: Myocardial Infarction in LRRC10 knockout mice
